awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Secure and Trustworthy Provenance for Accountable Clouds
awd_abstract_narration:
Cloud computing has emerged as one of the most successful computing models in recent years. However, lack of accountability and non-compliance with data protection regulations have prevented major users such as business, healthcare, and defense organizations from utilizing clouds for sensitive data and applications. Due to the lack of information about cloud internals and the inability to perform trustworthy audits, today's clouds are often not used in regulated industries, preventing their widespread adoption. 

The main focus of this project is to make clouds more accountable by leveraging provenance or the history of data, applications, and cloud state as a first-class property of clouds. The cloud provenance architecture provides mechanisms for collecting, storing, and securing provenance, and creating a secure access mechanism for provenance. We implement our architecture using OpenStack - a popular cloud platform - and use standard benchmarks to evaluate performance. 

A secure provenance based cloud advances the state-of-the-art in several ways: (i) it makes clouds more accountable, trustworthy, and secure; (ii) which leads to increased adoption of clouds by large organizations; (iii) this ultimately lowers the cost; (iv) it also provides law-enforcement with support for digital forensics investigations in clouds; and finally (v) it allows innovations such as novel authentication and access-control schemes. 

This research is accompanied by an integrated educational component, including development of new curricula, textbook, and an online course. The project also includes mentoring of K-12, undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral researchers, summer camps, and active involvement of women and minorities in order to increase the diversity of our nation's workforce.

Project Goal and Team

The goal of this project was to develop mechanisms to make cloud computing secure and trustworthy. This CAREER award to PI Dr. Ragib Hasan was also aimed at enabling Hasan to pursue research and scholarly activities and to broaden participation of minorities and underrepresented students.  

Hasan mentored PhD, Masters, undergraduate, and highschool students at his UAB SECuRE and Trustworthy Computing Lab at the University of Alabama at Birmingham.

 

Motivation and Research

In everyday lives, humans extensively use the notion of provenance or history to establish trust and make decisions. For example, when meeting someone, our trust levels depend on our familiarity with the individual. Real life trust is never binary -- it depends on past interactions between us and the individual. Similarly, trust on the authenticity of objects such as art depend on the existence of verifiable history records, also known as provenance. 

Hasan's key insight is that we could apply the concept of provenance to make digital objects more trustworthy. To do that, we need a mechanism to make the generation, propagation, and preservation of provenance secure. In distributed systems, enforcing the security of provenance is difficult. Hasan specifically explored how to make provenance secure and trustworthy in cloud computing. He has created novel techniques for protecting the integrity of provenance in clouds. 

Secure cloud provenance is extremely important. By design, clouds are distributed entities with many actors. The cloud service provider can control many aspects while users have no control. A key challenge is to design mechanisms that prevent a cloud service provider from falsifying provenance. 

Hasan solved this problem by creating methods to preserve the integrity of provenance information via secure provenance chain and then preserving its integrity using a Bloom-filter-based method. Hasan also implemented and tested the secure provenance scheme on OpenStack -- a popular cloud computing platform. 

Hasan also explored the application of the concept in other domains. Hasan was the first to introduce the concept of Interaction Provenance -- the history of interaction between two entities -- that can be used as a fundamental building block of security. Hasan demonstrated that this powerful concept of Interaction Provenance can be used as a generalization of authentication factors as well as in access control. Hasan further expanded the use of his provenance integrity solutions in the domain of Internet of Things, Cloud Forensics, and Secure and Connected Autonomous Vehicles. 

Hasan has explored some novel ideas in related domains. This includes Hasan's Wearable cloud Jacket -- a fully functional cloud computing system that can be worn by a user in a jacket. Hasan also developed the smart bracelet -- a wearable device that can provide safety to women and children in case of accidents or attacks. Additionally, Hasan developed a secure location provenance scheme for mobile devices.

 

Intellectual Merits and Project Technical Outcomes

  • 1. A complete Secure Cloud Provenance scheme. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first system designed for secure cloud provenance.
  • 2. A mechanism for securing the integrity of logs in clouds
  • 3. Mechanisms for ensuring trustworthiness of Cloud Forensics
  • 4. Introduction and development of the concept of Interaction Provenance and its use as a fundamental building block of authentication and access control
  • 5. Use of provenance and related techniques developed in the project to secure IoT
  • 6. Use of secure provenance techniques to ensure the integrity of location provenance
  • 7. Use of secure provenance to ensure the security of Connected Autonomous Vehicles
The technical results were disseminated through the publications of of 27 peer-reviewed conference and journal papers, which are available at Hasan's lab webpage: https://sites.uab.edu/secret

 

Broader Impacts on Educational and Workforce Development

To develop the future workforce of our nation, Hasan trained students in his lab. Hasan also successfully mentored multiple students belonging to minority and underrepresented groups, thereby increasing the diversity in computer science.

  • 1. Graduated of 5 PhD students, all successfully employed in academia or industry
  • 2. Graduated of 2 Masters Students, both successfully working as software professionals
  • 3. Mentored a hispanic and a female undergraduate student
  • 4. Mentored to a female highschool student
  • 5. Developed two courses: CS643 Cloud Security and CS633 Cloud Computing

 

Broader Impacts on Society 

The promise of provenance in cybersecurity is endless -- it shows that we can take human-centered processes into the digital domain and use it to make computing more trustworthy. The societal impacts are in increased trust on clouds. Ultimately, it increases adoption of clouds, benefiting the society.

 

Other Achievements

  • 1. Research from this project was featured on NSF funded Science Nation episode: "Clothes make the cloud" in this lab, November 13, 2017, https://www.nsf.gov/news/mmg/mmg_disp.jsp?med_id=185829&from=
  • 2. Best Poster Award, IEEE INFOCOM 2018.
  • 3. Runner-up, Best Demo Award, IEEE CCNC 2018. 
  • 4. UAB Dean's Award for Mentorship, 2020 for mentoring PhD, MS, and undergraduate students

 

Further Information

See:https://sites.uab.edu/secret
